data.title: mouse-wheel scroll on integrated terminal scrolls 1 line at a time
data.body:
- VSCode Version: 1.3.0
- OS Version: Xenial

Steps to Reproduce:
1. Print a lot of text to the integrated terminal
2. Scroll the mouse wheel

Notice that the mouse-wheel scrolls one line at a time... this is really slow, and not like other terminals (gnome terminal scrolls 4 lines at a time by default).
Would be nice if mouse-scroll did scroll the normal amount of lines.

data.title: Multiline Find seems not work completely

milestone.title: Backlog
milestone.description: Work not yet planned for a specific release.

data.body:
- VSCode Version: 1.3
- OS Version: Win 8/10

Version 1.3 supported Multiline Find, but Regular Expression seems not work completely.
- `\s` doesn't match line breaks.
- `[^]` doesn't match line breaks. We have to use `[\s\S\n]` instead of `[^]` to make it match any character.

data.title: CTRL+<Right|Left> arrow is not working in integrated console
data.body:
- VSCode Version: 1.3.0
- OS Version: Windows 10

In the editor, and in general many consoles, Ctrl+Right or Left arrow moves the cursor left or right by a word. This functionality is immensely helpful within the integrated console too. At the moment, in the integrated console, this key combination results in inserting '5D'. 

Steps to Reproduce:
1. Open Integrated Console
2. Type a command and then try Ctrl+Left

data.title: Many issues with styling different tokens
data.body:
Hello,

I recently started trying to build a custom theme from scratch and I've run into a few issues as well as find it very confusing to know which selectors are applied where.

One issue I've noticed in certain places is the assignment operator `=` appears to not be it's own token making it impossible to style separately:
https://cl.ly/3M2I3y0u0K1q

A similar issue happens sometimes with the property separator `:`, which ruins the ability to style both the separator and whatever follows:
https://cl.ly/3M2I3y0u0K1q

And the declaration and comparison operators `=`,`==`,`===` all have the exact same classes, at least most of the time:
https://cl.ly/3M2I3y0u0K1q

Sometimes the classes they have are completely different and not specific enough to pinpoint the right tokens:
https://cl.ly/100S2w3X1T0n

These are just a few of the issues I'm seeing when trying to style different parts of the syntax.  What I was expecting to be able to do was to use a selector like `operator.declaration` to color all `=`'s, and something like `operator.comparison` to target all `==`,`!=`,`===`,`!==`, etc..

Maybe these are leftovers from TextMate theming?  Or maybe I'm just missing something about the way these classes/themes are supposed to work?

I'm also open to contributing, but some guidance would be helpful.

data.title: Clear search scope when find widget is hidden
data.body:
- VSCode Version: 1.3.0
- OS Version: macOS X El Capitan 10.11.5 (15F34)

Steps to Reproduce:
1. Open a Markdown file (`.md`)
2. Select a fragment that has the `bold` formatting included (`**`).
3. Use `Command + F` to Find, then expand the little popup to `Replace`.
4. In the replace field, type in the code delimiter character (```).
5. Perform replace.
6. Now press `ESC` and select another line that has `bold` formatting included (`**`).
7. `Command + F` to find - notice that it says `No results`

![screenshot 2016-07-10 17 11 35](https://cloud.githubusercontent.com/assets/1389609/16717051/653d32ee-46c2-11e6-90af-db4ba2caf69d.png)

data.title: output window is not realtime!
data.body:
- VSCode Version: 1.3
- OS Version: 8.1-64

hi, i wrote a simple python script and run it from output window(not terminal):

```
for i in range(1,1000001):
    print i
```

after while output window show: 1,2,3,...,9568
then output will freeze and again after while show another part: 9569,9570,...,18536
and again,again,again... 

**BUT** if i run this script in terminal, all numbers will print one after another: 1,2,3,4,....,1000000

in the other words: output window is not real time or live!

data.title: Support sanctioned package.json comment style
data.body:
# Suggestion

`npm` sanctions the use of the `"//"` property for comments in `project.json` [[1]](https://groups.google.com/forum/#!msg/nodejs/NmL7jdeuw0M/yTqI05DRQrIJ) [[2]](https://github.com/npm/npm/issues/4482#issuecomment-32267045), but vscode JSON intellisense complains. Allow this comment style in project.json files in opened npm project folders.
## Environment
- VSCode Version: 1.3
- OS Version: Windows 10
## Steps to Reproduce
1. Add `"//": "...",` to `project.json`.
2. Observe green undersquiggle with tooltip: `Duplicate object key`.

![vscode-issue](https://cloud.githubusercontent.com/assets/3524633/16716658/ed7402d6-46c8-11e6-8f21-6ed8db8ccf8f.PNG)

- OS Version:  Fedora Workstation 4.6.3-300.fc24.x86_64

I have some trouble to install 'vscode' after cloning and installing the project from Github.
I use a fresh Fedora Workstation Installation (fc24.x86_64) virtualized on VMware.

Please see the attached screen dump:

![vscode_install_error](https://cloud.githubusercontent.com/assets/20271294/16716623/20d6d322-4702-11e6-9801-055925081bb1.png)

Steps to Reproduce:
1. Clone 'vscode' Branch 'release/1.3.0' to a local repository (git clone https://github.com/microsoft/vscode)
2. cd vscode
3. ./scripts/npm.sh install --arch=x64

Please help.

Thanks for your support.

data.title: VSCode should self-configure debug settings when added to ASP.NET Core projects
data.body:
- VSCode Version: 1.3.0
- OS Version: Windows 10

Steps to Reproduce:
1. Create ASP.NET Core project using either Visual Studio 2013 or via Yeoman ("yo aspnet") at the command-line
2. At the command-line, navigate to the root of the project (wherever project.json resides)
3. Run `dotnet restore`: Dependencies should be downloaded
4. Run `dotnet run`: Project should build & run
5. Run `code .`: VS Code should load and open the project folder
6. Open debug tab and hit "play button": VS Code displays an error that "launch.json must be configured"
   ![saved image from tweetium](https://cloud.githubusercontent.com/assets/961950/16714984/52e9b980-4688-11e6-9af5-3264bedd456c.jpg)

I [asked about this on Twitter](https://twitter.com/bitcrazed/status/751464295121063936) and received help from @jchannon, @shanselman and @damianedwards (thanks guys): Turns out that I had to manually determine the `target-framework` and `project-name` fields. I also had to [set the "debugType": "portable" in project.json](https://github.com/bitcrazed/HelloWorldCore/commit/7c34f86998dc53e0a0d4409e7e130f540890b0b0). (see [request to set this by default](https://github.com/aspnet/Templates/issues/650))

I would have expected that since VS Code injected `launch.json` into the project, and that it had access to `project.json` etc. that it'd be able to determine the target-framework automatically.

data.title: Request: Add a way for exstensions to show an update log
data.body:
I think it would be very nice to have a way to display logs of new features and bug fixes after an update of an extension, similarly to [what the PackageControl-Plugin from Sublime Text offers](https://packagecontrol.io/docs/messaging).

<sup>I couldn't find any trace of a way to add update logs for Code-extensions, but feel free to point me in the direction if I just missed it ;)</sup>

data.title: Column selection with CJK character
data.body:
- VSCode Version: 1.3.0
- OS Version: Windows 10 64-bit

Steps to Reproduce:
1. Copy and paste the following Chinese, Japanese and English sentences to VS code.

```
äººäººç”Ÿè€Œè‡ªç”±ï¼Œåœ¨å°Šä¸¥å’Œæƒåˆ©ä¸Šä¸€å¾‹å¹³ç­‰ã€‚
ã™ã¹ã¦ã®äººé–“ã¯ã€ç”Ÿã¾ã‚ŒãªãŒã‚‰ã«ã—ã¦è‡ªç”±ã§ã‚ã‚Šã€ã‹ã¤ã€å°ŠåŽ³ã¨æ¨©åˆ©ã¨ ã«ã¤ã„ã¦å¹³ç­‰ã§ã‚ã‚‹ã€‚
All human beings are born free and equal in dignity and rights.
```

The sentences above are official translation of UDHR.
2. Use Shift + Alt + Click to select columns.

The behavior is:
![vscode](https://cloud.githubusercontent.com/assets/8521174/16713563/c33558c8-46ee-11e6-9c17-5a962782a5de.gif)

CJK characters are usually have double width than other characters. So visually the column of CJK characters and English characters are not same. When I use column selection to select CJK/English mixed codes this issue will affect the result.

The expected behavior is like what Sublime Text does:
![sublime](https://cloud.githubusercontent.com/assets/8521174/16713579/e4b0cce8-46ef-11e6-932e-df92c4453f4a.gif)
